• RIGHT from (2,0) leads to (3,0), which is free and lies along the bottom row toward our target apple at (6,0).

Thus, moving RIGHT remains the safest option while moving us closer to that apple.

Strategy note for future turns: Continue aiming for the bottom-row apple at (6,0) while keeping an eye out for any potential blocks from enemy movements or walls.

My decided next move is: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Let’s re‐evaluate from our current head at (7,1):

Possible moves:
 • UP → (7,2) is free  
 • RIGHT → (8,1) is free  
 • LEFT → back into our neck at (7,0) (illegal)  
 • DOWN → off the board (illegal)

Our closest apple is at (8,3) (Manhattan distance = 3).  

– If we go UP to (7,2), we’d then need RIGHT→(8,2), UP→(8,3).  
– If we go RIGHT to (8,1), we can then do UP→(8,2), UP→(8,3).  

Both are safe, but pushing RIGHT first gives us a straighter line to (8,3) and keeps us out of tight space near our own body. After that apple, we can sweep toward the cluster at (7,5)/(6,6)/(9,5)/(9,6).

Next move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
I’m looking at our snake’s head at (5,0). Here’s what the adjacent cells are according to the board:

• UP → (5,1) 
  At the moment, (5,1) is occupied by a part of enemy snake #0’s body.
• RIGHT → (6,0)
  That cell is also filled by an enemy body segment.
• LEFT → (4,0)
  Even though (4,0) is our own tail, moving directly backwards into it is forbidden.
• DOWN → (5,–1)
  That’s off the board.

None of the four moves is “safe” on the static board. (In snake games both you and your foes will move simultaneously and usually the tail of a snake will be cleared if no apple is eaten, but the only cell that might get freed for us is our own tail, and even that is off‐limits because it would be considered “moving backwards”.)

I recognize that every adjacent cell is either already occupied by an enemy segment or is not allowed. In a situation like this there isn’t a “magic” safe move—but if forced to choose one, I’ll have to pick the move that (in theory) might give a slim chance if the enemy snake makes an unexpected move (or crashes into itself by accident).

My earlier planning was aimed at heading toward the apple at (8,3), so I would like to move upward. With our head at (5,0), that means going to (5,1), even though it’s currently held by enemy snake #0’s body. In typical Battlesnake rules if you move into an occupied cell you die but sometimes you’re in a no‐win situation. With no truly safe alternative, I choose UP as my next move and will hope that if the enemy snake’s body shifts (due to its tail being removed or an unexpected misstep) it might open a narrow window.

Next move: UP.
